Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Write clean, maintainable, and efficient code
Situation2: The new feature is nearly ready but performance warnings appear in code reviews
Story: My phone buzzed with a message from my younger sister: “Movie night with everyone at 7? You’re coming, right?” I glanced at the clock—6:15. I hadn’t seen her in weeks, and I knew how much she valued these little traditions. Being there would show her I cared, that I respected our bond enough to make time for her. But my laptop screen glared back at me, code editor open, red warnings scattered across my new feature. The team’s comments echoed in my mind: “Performance issues here,” “Needs refactoring.” I was so close to finishing, but I couldn’t ignore the standards we set for ourselves. Clean, efficient code wasn’t just a checkbox—it was my responsibility to the team. My heart pounded as I weighed the expectations: be the reliable brother who shows up, or the dependable developer who delivers quality work. I stared at the blinking cursor, torn between two worlds, feeling the pressure of letting someone down no matter what I chose.
